title: Get started
text: SEMs ubiquitous social sciences, psychology, ecology, fields. INLAvaan package provides user-friendly interface fitting Bayesian SEMs using Integrated Nested Laplace Approximations (INLA, Rue, Martino, Chopin 2009). vignette guide basics using INLAvaan fit simple SEM. begin make sure installed INLAvaan package GitHub running commands .
code: # Run this if you have not yet installed INLAvaan install.packages("pak") pak::pak("haziqj/INLAvaan")  # Load all libraries for this example library(INLAvaan) library(tidyverse) library(lavaan)

title: Get started
text: motivate use SEMs, consider introductory example Song Lee (2012): poorer glycemic control lead greater severity kidney disease? observe three indicators glycemic control (y1y_1, y2y_2, y3y_3) three indicators kidney disease severity (y4y_4, y5y_5, y6y_6).  Rather fitting separate regression models indicator, SEM allows us model relationship latent constructs , providing clearer coherent representation underlying processes. hypothesised SEM illustrated figure :

title: Get started
text: two-factor SEM described , easy simulate data using lavaan package . code : code , note true values parameters, including factor loadings Λ\Lambda, regression coefficient β\beta two latent variables, well residual latent variances Θ\Theta Ψ\Psi respectively.

title: Get started
text: Now simulated data, can fit SEM using INLAvaan. model syntax similar lavaan, making easy specify model. details model syntax, refer lavaan website. INLAvaan provides mirror functions main model fitting functions lavaan: acfa() mirrors lavaan::cfa() confirmatory factor analysis; asem() mirrors lavaan::sem() structural equation models; agrowth() mirrors lavaan::growth() latent growth curve models. code fit SEM model : INLAvaan computes approximation posterior density way Laplace approximation (Tierney, Kass, Kadane 1989). joint mode Hessian needs computed, gives Gaussian distribution joint posterior parameters. default method optimisation stats::nlminb(), optimisers can used specifying optim_method = "ucminf" ucminf package optim_method = "optim" call stats::optim() function method "BFGS". , marginal posterior distributions parameter can obtained one several ways, including 1) Skew normal fitting (marginal_method = "skewnorm", default method, see Chiuchiolo, Van Niekerk, Rue 2023); 2) Two-piece asymmetric Gaussian fitting (marginal_method = "asymgaus", see Martins et al. 2013); 3) Direct marginalisation joint Gaussian posterior (marginal_method = "marggaus"); 4) Sampling joint Gaussian posterior (marginal_method = "sampling"). marginal posterior distributions obtained, can use compute derived quantities interest via copula sampling. posterior predictive p-values (Gelman, Meng, Stern 1996) Deviance Information Criterion (DIC, Spiegelhalter et al. 2002) computed way. Often, posterior sampling takes longer model fitting , number samples can controlled via nsamp argument (default nsamp = 1000) can skipped altoghether (test = "none").
code: mod <- "   eta1 =~ y1 + y2 + y3   eta2 =~ y4 + y5 + y6   eta2 ~ eta1 " fit <- asem(mod, dat) #> ℹ Finding posterior mode. #> ✔ Finding posterior mode. [81ms] #>  #> ℹ Computing the Hessian. #> ✔ Computing the Hessian. [88ms] #>  #> ℹ Performing VB correction. #> ✔ VB correction; mean |δ| = 0.003σ. [124ms] #>  #> ⠙ Fitting skew normal to 0/13 marginals. #> ✔ Fitting skew normal to 13/13 marginals. [351ms] #>  #> ⠙ Computing ppp and DIC. #> ⠹ Computing ppp and DIC. #> ✔ Computing ppp and DIC. [342ms] #>

title: Get started
text: resulting object class INLAvaan, subclass lavaan objects. result, methods work lavaan objects also work INLAvaan objects. common ones probably coef() summary(). ’s possible request posterior medians modes summary output specifying postmedian = TRUE postmode = TRUE summary() function. Predicted values latent variables can obtained using predict() function. done sampling posterior distributions latent variables given observed data. future, function also allow --sample predictions also retrieve predictions observed variables. S3 object summary method provides posterior means credible intervals latent variables. Alternatively, user welcome perform summary statistics list posterior samples returned predict(). simple plot method provided view marginal posterior distributions parameters. vertical lines indicate posterior mode.

title: Get started
text: addition several global fit indices (.e. PPP, DIC), possible compare models way Bayes factors using compare() function. function takes two INLAvaan objects computes Bayes factor using Laplace approximations marginal likelihoods. note, several criticisms use Bayes factors model comparison, particularly context SEMs (Tendeiro Kiers 2019; Schad et al. 2023). blavaan package able implement WAICs LOOs alternative model comparison metrics, hopefully also implemented future versions INLAvaan.

title: Get started
text: INLAvaan package uses prior specification syntax blavaan (Merkle Rosseel 2018; Merkle et al. 2021), detailed . Essentially, two ways set priors model parameters: 1) Globally parameters certain type (e.g., factor loadings, regression coefficients, etc.); 2) Individually specific parameters model syntax. default global priors derived blavaan: Note , INLAvaan uses SRS decomposition variance matrices, consequently places priors correlations instead covariances. , instead wished set global priors, say Gamma distribution variances instead standard deviations (default), following: set individual priors specific parameters, can model syntax . instance, set normal prior mean 1 standard deviation 3 factor loading y3 eta1, normal prior mean 0 standard deviation 0.5 regression coefficient eta1 eta2, specify model follows:
code: blavaan::dpriors() #>                nu             alpha            lambda              beta  #>    "normal(0,32)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"  #>             theta               psi               rho             ibpsi  #> "gamma(1,.5)[sd]" "gamma(1,.5)[sd]"       "beta(1,1)" "wishart(3,iden)"  #>               tau  #>   "normal(0,1.5)" DP <- blavaan::dpriors(theta = "gamma(1,1)", psi = "gamma(1,1)") DP #>                nu             alpha            lambda              beta  #>    "normal(0,32)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"    "normal(0,10)"  #>             theta               psi               rho             ibpsi  #>      "gamma(1,1)"      "gamma(1,1)"       "beta(1,1)" "wishart(3,iden)"  #>               tau  #>   "normal(0,1.5)" ## fit <- asem(mod, dat, dpriors = DP)  # not run mod <- "   eta1 =~ y1 + y2 + prior('normal(1,3)')*y3   eta2 =~ y4 + y5 + y6   eta2 ~ prior('normal(0,.5)')*eta1 " ## fit <- asem(mod, dat)  # not run

text: Dependency R-INLA temporarily removed tThe current version INLAvaan (v0.2-0). wide class LVMs SEMs latent variables unstructured independent, current implementation sufficient. However, future versions INLAvaan re-introduce dependency R-INLA allow complex latent structures, spatial temporal dependencies.

title: Mediation Analysis
text: verify INLAvaan recovers correct parameters, simulate data “truth” known. logic follows: Generate… XX normally; MM dependent XX coefficient 0.5; YY dependent MM coefficient 0.7. Critically, add XX generation YY. means true direct effect (cc) 0, relationship fully mediated. expect model estimate ≈0.5a \approx 0.5, b≈0.7b \approx 0.7, indirect effect ab≈0.35ab \approx 0.35. direct effect cc close zero.
code: set.seed(11) n <- 100  # sample size  # 1. Predictor X <- rnorm(n)  # 2. Mediator (Path a = 0.5) M <- 0.5 * X + rnorm(n)  # 3. Outcome (Path b = 0.7, Path c = 0) Y <- 0.7 * M + rnorm(n)   dat <- data.frame(X = X, Y = Y, M = M)

title: Mediation Analysis
text: standard lavaan syntax mediation model straightforward (note use := operator define indirect effect new parameter.): model fit using asem(). meanstructure = TRUE argument supplied estimate intercepts variables. user may wish specify different prior distributions parameters. See relevant section Get started vignetted details.
code: mod <- "   # Direct effect (path c)   Y ~ c*X    # Mediator paths (path a and b)   M ~ a*X   Y ~ b*M    # Define Indirect effect (a*b)   ab := a*b    # Define Total effect   total := c + (a*b) " library(INLAvaan) fit <- asem(mod, dat, meanstructure = TRUE) #> ℹ Finding posterior mode. #> ✔ Finding posterior mode. [28ms] #>  #> ℹ Computing the Hessian. #> ✔ Computing the Hessian. [63ms] #>  #> ℹ Performing VB correction. #> ✔ VB correction; mean |δ| = 0.012σ. [172ms] #>  #> ⠙ Fitting skew normal to 0/7 marginals. #> ✔ Fitting skew normal to 7/7 marginals. [198ms] #>  #> ⠙ Computing ppp and DIC. #> ✔ Computing ppp and DIC. [367ms] #>

title: Mediation Analysis
text: summary output provides posterior mean, standard deviation, 95% credible intervals paths. Looking Regressions Defined Parameters sections output: intercepts non-significant, since simulated data true means zero. Path aa (M ~ X) estimated 0.525 (true value 0.5). Path bb (Y ~ M) estimated 0.771 (true value 0.7). Path cc (Y ~ X) estimated -0.060. 95% Credible Interval [-0.291, 0.171] includes zero, correctly identifying direct effect. Indirect Effect abab estimated 0.403 (true value 0.35). interval [0.249, 0.593] cross zero, indicating significant mediation. sum direct indirect effects (c+abc + ab). tells us 1-unit increase XX leads total increase roughly 0.347 YY. Note: simulation, even though direct effect non-significant (close zero), total effect significant mechanism via MM strong. illustrates “full mediation” scenario: XX affects YY, MM.

title: Missing Values
code: library(INLAvaan) mod <- "     # Latent variable definitions     ind60 =~ x1 + x2 + x3     dem60 =~ y1 + y2 + y3 + y4     dem65 =~ y5 + y6 + y7 + y8      # Latent regressions     dem60 ~ ind60     dem65 ~ ind60 + dem60      # Residual correlations     y1 ~~ y5     y2 ~~ y4 + y6     y3 ~~ y7     y4 ~~ y8     y6 ~~ y8   " dat <- lavaan::PoliticalDemocracy  # Simulate missingness (MCAR) set.seed(221) mis <- matrix(rbinom(prod(dim(dat)), 1, 0.99), nrow(dat), ncol(dat)) datmiss <- dat * mis datmiss[datmiss == 0] <- NA

title: Multilevel SEM
text: use Demo.twolevel dataset included R package lavaan, make easier follow, interpret variables within educational context. data contains following information: Clusters (cluster): 200 different schools. Observations: 2500 students nested within schools. Outcomes (y1, y2, y3): Three distinct survey items measuring “Academic Performance.” Within-level Predictors (x1, x2, x3): Student-specific factors Study Hours, Sleep Hours, Attendance. -level Predictors (w1, w2): School-level factors Teacher Experience, School Budget. model, assume two latent variables: fw measuring individual students aptitude (.e. student ability) fb measuring school quality, .e. shared variance performance attributable school environment. envisaged two-level SEM can visualized follows:
code: graph LR      %% --- Level 1: Within (Student) ---     subgraph L1 [Level 1: Within-Student]         direction LR         x1[x1] & x2[x2] & x3[x3] --> fw((fw))         fw --> y1_w[y1] & y2_w[y2] & y3_w[y3]     end      %% --- Separator (Invisible edge to force stacking if needed) ---     L1 ~~~ L2      %% --- Level 2: Between (School) ---     subgraph L2 [Level 2: Between-School]         direction LR         w1[w1] & w2[w2] --> fb((fb))         fb --> y1_b[y1] & y2_b[y2] & y3_b[y3]     end          %% --- Styling ---     classDef latent fill:#f9f9f9,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px,shape:circle;     classDef observed fill:#fff,stroke:#333,stroke-width:1px,shape:rect;      class fw,fb latent;     class x1,x2,x3,w1,w2,y1_b,y2_b,y3_b,y1_w,y2_w,y3_w observed;

title: Multilevel SEM
text: First, load INLAvaan dataset.

title: Multilevel SEM
text: INLAvaan (following lavaan syntax), specify model level using level: <block> keywords. example, Level 1: define latent variable fw (Student Ability) regress individual predictors (x). Level 2: define latent variable fb (School Quality) regress school-level predictors (w). use asem() function (Approximate SEM) fit model. Crucially, must specify cluster argument identify grouping variable.
code: mod <- "   level: 1       # Measurement model (Within-student)       fw =~ y1 + y2 + y3       # Structural model: Individual predictors       fw ~ x1 + x2 + x3    level: 2       # Measurement model (Between-school)       fb =~ y1 + y2 + y3       # Structural model: School-level predictors       fb ~ w1 + w2 " fit <- asem(mod, data = Demo.twolevel, cluster = "cluster") #> ℹ Finding posterior mode. #> ✔ Finding posterior mode. [558ms] #>  #> ℹ Computing the Hessian. #> ✔ Computing the Hessian. [688ms] #>  #> ℹ Performing VB correction. #> ✔ VB correction; mean |δ| = 0.021σ. [619ms] #>  #> ⠙ Fitting skew normal to 0/20 marginals. #> ⠹ Fitting skew normal to 12/20 marginals. #> ✔ Fitting skew normal to 20/20 marginals. [3.4s] #>  #> ⠙ Computing ppp and DIC. #> ✔ Computing ppp and DIC. [822ms] #>

title: Multilevel SEM
text: summary output provides Bayesian estimates (posterior means, standard deviations, credible intervals) levels. Notice , mean structure automatically included levels, intercepts observed variables estimated default. required ‘’ component specifically models variation cluster means; without estimating means (intercepts), impossible decompose variance within levels. Looking output , can draw substantive conclusions based educational scenario: Level 1 [within] Regressions path fw ~ x1 0.510. suggests every unit increase x1 (e.g., Study Hours), student’s individual ability (fw) increases significantly. Level 2 [cluster] Regressions path fb ~ w1 0.164 suggests positive relationship school-level factors (like Teacher Experience) overall School Quality (fb), though standard deviation wider due smaller sample size Level 2 (n=200n=200 schools vs n=2500n=2500 students). Latent Variables: loadings y1, y2, y3 fw fb significant (0 included credible interval) thus confirm survey items effectively measure individual ability school-level quality.

title: Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis
text: Efficient approximate Bayesian inference Structural Equation Models. Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods remain gold standard exact Bayesian inference, can prohibitively slow iterative model development. INLAvaan offers rapid alternative latent variable analysis, delivering Bayesian results (near) speed frequentist estimators. achieves custom, ground-implementation Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA), engineered specifically lavaan modelling framework.

title: Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis
text: INLAvaan designed fit seamlessly existing workflow. familiar (b)lavaan syntax, can begin using INLAvaan immediately. first impression package, consider canonical example SEM applied Industrialisation Political Democracy data set Bollen (1989)1:

what: INLAvaan: Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis — INLAvaan-package
title: INLAvaan: Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis — INLAvaan-package
text: Implements approximate Bayesian inference Structural Equation Models (SEM) using custom adaptation Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation described Rue et al. (2009) doi:10.1111/j.1467-9868.2008.00700.x . Provides computationally efficient alternative Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) Bayesian estimation, allowing users fit latent variable models using 'lavaan' syntax.

title: INLAvaan: Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Analysis — INLAvaan-package
text: acfa(): Approximate Confirmatory Factor Analysis. asem(): Approximate Structural Equation Modelling. agrowth(): Approximate Latent Growth Curve models.

code: acfa(   model,   data,   dp = blavaan::dpriors(),   marginal_method = c("skewnorm", "asymgaus", "marggaus", "sampling"),   nsamp = 500,   test = "standard",   marginal_correction = c("shortcut", "hessian", "none"),   sn_fit_logthresh = -6,   sn_fit_temp = NA,   control = list(),   verbose = TRUE,   debug = FALSE,   add_priors = TRUE,   optim_method = c("nlminb", "ucminf", "optim"),   numerical_grad = FALSE,   ... )

title: Fit an Approximate Bayesian Confirmatory Factor Analysis Model — acfa
text: model description user-specified model. Typically, model     described using lavaan model syntax. See     model.syntax information. Alternatively,     parameter table (eg. output lavParTable() function) also     accepted. data optional data frame containing observed variables used     model. variables declared ordered factors, lavaan     treat ordinal variables. dp Default prior distributions different types     parameters, typically result call dpriors().     See dpriors() help file information. marginal_method method approximating marginal posterior distributions. Options include "skewnorm" (skew normal), "asymgaus" (two-piece asymmetric Gaussian), "marggaus" (marginalising Laplace approximation), "sampling" (sampling joint Laplace approximation). nsamp number samples draw sampling-based approaches (including posterior sampling model fit indices). test Character indicating whether compute posterior fit indices. Defaults "standard". Change "none" skip computations. marginal_correction type correction use fitting skew normal two-piece Gaussian marginals. "hessian" computes full Hessian-based correction (slow), "shortcut" (default) computes diagonals, "none" (FALSE) applies correction. sn_fit_logthresh log-threshold fitting skew normal. Points log-posterior drop threshold (relative maximum) excluded fit. Defaults -6. sn_fit_temp Temperature parameter fitting skew normal. NA, temperature included optimisation skew normal fit. control list control parameters optimiser. verbose Logical indicating whether print progress messages. debug Logical indicating whether return debug information. add_priors Logical indicating whether include prior densities posterior computation. optim_method optimisation method use finding posterior mode. Options include "nlminb" (default), "ucminf", "optim" (BFGS). numerical_grad Logical indicating whether use numerical gradients optimisation. ... Additional arguments passed lavaan::lavaan model fitting function.

title: Fit a skew normal distribution to log-density evaluations — fit_skew_normal
code: library(sn) #> Loading required package: stats4 #>  #> Attaching package: ‘sn’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     sd library(tidyr) library(ggplot2)  logdens <- function(x) dgamma(x, shape = 3, rate = 1, log = TRUE)  x_grid <- seq(0.1, 8, length.out = 21) y_log <- sapply(x_grid, logdens) y_log <- y_log - max(y_log) # normalise to have maximum at zero  res <- fit_skew_normal(x_grid, y_log, temp = 10) unlist(res) #>           xi        omega        alpha         logC            k         rmse  #>  0.842445393  2.539226101  3.310505376  1.332422700 10.000000000  0.002109188  #>         nmad  #>  0.173298470   plot_df <-   pivot_longer(     tibble(       x = seq(0.1, 8, length.out = 200),       truth = exp(logdens(x)),       approx = dsnorm(x, xi = res$xi, omega = res$omega, alpha = res$alpha)     ),     cols = c("truth", "approx"),     names_to = "type",     values_to = "density"   )  ggplot() +   # truth as filled area   geom_area(     data = subset(plot_df, type == "truth"),     aes(x, density, fill = "Truth"),     alpha = 0.38   ) +   # approx as blue line   geom_line(     data = subset(plot_df, type == "approx"),     aes(x = x, y = density, col = "SN Approx."),     linewidth = 1   ) +   scale_fill_manual(name = NULL, values = "#131516") +   scale_colour_manual(name = NULL, values = "#00A6AA") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "top")

title: Fit an Approximate Bayesian Latent Variable Model — inlavaan
text: model description user-specified model. Typically, model     described using lavaan model syntax. See     model.syntax information. Alternatively,     parameter table (eg. output lavParTable() function) also     accepted. data optional data frame containing observed variables used     model. variables declared ordered factors, lavaan     treat ordinal variables. model.type Set model type: possible values     "cfa", "sem" "growth". may affect     starting values computed, may used alter terminology     used summary output, layout path diagrams     based fitted lavaan object. dp Default prior distributions different types     parameters, typically result call dpriors().     See dpriors() help file information. vb_correction Logical indicating whether apply variational Bayes correction posterior mean vector estimates. Defaults TRUE. marginal_method method approximating marginal posterior distributions. Options include "skewnorm" (skew normal), "asymgaus" (two-piece asymmetric Gaussian), "marggaus" (marginalising Laplace approximation), "sampling" (sampling joint Laplace approximation). marginal_correction type correction use fitting skew normal two-piece Gaussian marginals. "hessian" computes full Hessian-based correction (slow), "shortcut" (default) computes diagonals, "none" (FALSE) applies correction. nsamp number samples draw sampling-based approaches (including posterior sampling model fit indices). test Character indicating whether compute posterior fit indices. Defaults "standard". Change "none" skip computations. sn_fit_logthresh log-threshold fitting skew normal. Points log-posterior drop threshold (relative maximum) excluded fit. Defaults -6. sn_fit_temp Temperature parameter fitting skew normal. NA, temperature included optimisation skew normal fit. control list control parameters optimiser. verbose Logical indicating whether print progress messages. debug Logical indicating whether return debug information. add_priors Logical indicating whether include prior densities posterior computation. optim_method optimisation method use finding posterior mode. Options include "nlminb" (default), "ucminf", "optim" (BFGS). numerical_grad Logical indicating whether use numerical gradients optimisation. ... title: Fast Approximation of Skew-Normal Quantile Function — qsnorm_fast
text: function implements high-performance approximation skew-normal quantile function based algorithm described Luu (2016). method uses domain decomposition strategy achieve high accuracy (\(< 10^{-7}\) relative error) without iterative numerical inversion. domain split two regions: Tail Regions: extreme probabilities \(\vert u \vert\) large, quantile approximated using Lambert W-function, \(W(z)\), solving \(z = \Phi(q)\) via asymptotic expansion: $$q \approx \sqrt{2 W\left(\frac{1}{2\pi (1-p)^2}\right)}$$ Central Region: main body distribution, function uses high-order Taylor expansion inverse error function around carefully selected expansion point $x_0$: $$\Phi^{-1}(p) \approx \sum_{k=0}^5 c_k (z - x_0)^k$$ approach significantly faster standard numerical inversion (e.g., uniroot) maintaining sufficient precision statistical applications.

title: Fast Approximation of Skew-Normal Quantile Function — qsnorm_fast
text: Luu, T. (2016). Fast accurate parallel computation quantile functions random number generation #' (Doctoral thesis). UCL (University College London). https://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/1482128/

title: INLAvaan 0.2.2
text: CRAN release: 2026-01-27 hood, use lavaan’s MVN log-likelihood function compute single- multi-level log-likelihoods. Added support multi-level SEM models. Added support binary data using PML estimator lavaan. NOTE: Ordinal possible theory, package still lacks proper prior support thresholds. Added support missing = "ML" handle FIML missing data. Improved axis scanning, skewness correction, VB mean correction routine.

title: INLAvaan 0.2.1
text: Support lavaan 0.6-21. Implemented variational Bayes mean correction posterior marginals. Defined parameters now available, e.g. mediation analysis. Prepare CRAN release.

title: INLAvaan 0.2
text: INLAvaan rewritten ground specifically SEM models. new version call R-INLA directly, instead uses core approximation ideas fit SEM models efficiently. Features restricted normal likelihoods continuous observations now. Support models lavaan/blavaan can fit, including CFA, SEM, growth curve models. Support multigroup analysis. Added PPP DIC model fit indices. Added prior specification model parameters. Added support fixed values parameter constraints. Initial CRAN submission.

title: INLAvaan 0.1
text: Used rgeneric functionality R-INLA implement basic SEM framework.
